hints.content:
You pay $\blueD{\$35}$ for each month of your membership. The total cost depends on $\goldD m$, the number of months you are a member. 

To find the total cost, $\maroonD c$, we can use the equation $\maroonD c=\blueD{35}\goldD m$.

To find the cost of the yoga membership for $\goldD{20}$ months, we can substitute $\goldD{20}$ into the equation for $\goldD m$.

$\begin{align} \maroonD c &= \blueD{35}\goldD m\\
\maroonD c&= \blueD{35}\cdot \goldD{20} \\
\maroonD c &= 700 \end{align}$

The equation is $c=35m$. 

The  yoga membership will cost $\$700$ for $20$ months.

question.content:
A membership at a yoga studio costs $\$35$ per month. 

**Write an equation for the cost of the membership, $c$, that you pay if you keep your membership for $m$ months.**

[[☃ expression 1]]


 **How much will your membership cost if you keep it for $20$ months?**

 $\$$ [[☃ input-number 1]]

hints.content:
You earn $\blueD{\$12}$ each time you mow the lawn. The number of dollars you earn depends on $\goldD m$, the number of times you mow.

To find the number of dollars you earn, $\maroonD d$, we can use the equation $\maroonD d=\blueD{12}\goldD m$.

To find the number of dollars you earn if you mow the lawn  $\goldD{10}$ times, we can substitute $\goldD{10}$ into the equation for $\goldD m$.

$\begin{align} \maroonD d &= \blueD{12}\goldD m\\
\maroonD d&= \blueD{12}\cdot \goldD{10} \\
\maroonD d &= 120\end{align}$

The equation is $d=12m$. 

You will earn $\$120$ if you mow the lawn $10$ times.

question.content:
You mow the lawn to earn your allowance. Each time you mow the lawn you earn $\$12$. 


**Write an equation for the number of dollars, $d$, you earn when you mow the lawn $m$ times.**

[[☃ expression 1]]

 **How many dollars will you earn if you mow the lawn $10$ times?**

 $\$$ [[☃ input-number 3]]

hints.content:
You plan to read $\blueD{30}$ more minutes than your brother. The number of minutes you read depends on $\goldD x$, the number of minutes your brother reads.

To find the number of minutes you will read, $\maroonD y$, we can use the equation $\maroonD y=\goldD x \blueD{+30}$.

To find the number of minutes you will read if your brother reads for $\goldD{15}$ minutes, we can substitute $\goldD{15}$ into the equation for $\goldD x$.

$\begin{align} \maroonD y &=\goldD x+ \blueD{30}\\
\maroonD y&= \goldD{15} + \blueD{30}\\
\maroonD y &= 45\end{align}$

The equation is $y = x + 30$. 

You will read for $45$ minutes.

question.content:
You and your brother are reading the same novel. You want to get ahead of him in the book, so you decide to read $30$ minutes longer than your brother reads. 

**Write an equation for the number of minutes you read, $y$, when your brother reads $x$ number of minutes.**

[[☃ expression 2]]

 **How many minutes will you read if your brother reads for $15$ minutes?**

 [[☃ input-number 1]] minutes

hints.content:
Venla is $\blueD{5}$ years older than Kora. The age of Venla depends on $\goldD k$, the age of Kora.

To find the age of Venla, $\maroonD v$, we can use the equation $\maroonD v=\goldD k \blueD{+5}$.

To find the age of Kora if Venla is $\maroonD{18}$ years old, we can substitute $\maroonD{18}$ into the equation for $\maroonD v$.

Then we can subtract $\blueD5$ from both sides:

$\begin{align} \maroonD v &=\goldD k+ \blueD{5}\\
\maroonD{18}&= \goldD{k} + \blueD{5}\\
\maroonD{18} \blueD{-5} & = \goldD k + \blueD{5-5}\\
\goldD{13}&\goldD{= k}\end{align}$

The equation is $v = k + 5$. 

Kora is $13$ years old.

question.content:
Venla is $5$ years older than her cousin Kora. 

**Write an equation for the age of Venla, $v$, when Kora is $k$ years old.**

[[☃ expression 2]]

 **How old is Kora when Venla is $18$ years old?**

 [[☃ input-number 1]] years

hints.content:
You plan to swim $\blueD{15}$ more minutes than your friend. The number of minutes you swim depends on $\goldD x$, the number of minutes your friend swims.

To find the number of minutes you swim, $\maroonD y$, we can use the equation $\maroonD y=\goldD x \blueD{+15}$.

To find the number of minutes your friend swam if you swam for $\maroonD{55}$ minutes, we can substitute $\maroonD{55}$ into the equation for $\maroonD y$. 

Then we can subtract $\blueD{15}$ from both sides of the equation.

$\begin{align} \maroonD y &=\goldD x+ \blueD{15}\\
\maroonD{55}&= \goldD{x} + \blueD{15}\\
\maroonD{55}-\blueD{15}&= \goldD{x} + \blueD{15}-\blueD{15}\\
\goldD {40} &\goldD {=x}\end{align}$

The equation is $y = x + 15$. 

Your friend swam for $40$ minutes.

question.content:
You and your best friend are both on the swim team. You want to beat your friend at the next swim meet so you decide to swim $15$ minutes longer than she does one day at practice. 

**Write an equation for the number of minutes you swim, $y$, when your friend swims $x$ number of minutes.**

[[☃ expression 2]]


You swim $55$ minutes. 

 **How many minutes did your friend swim?**

 [[☃ input-number 1]] minutes

hints.content:
Tegan needs $\blueD{68}$ more blocks for her igloo. The number of blocks she still needs to make depends on $\goldD c$, the number of blocks she completes.

To find the number of blocks  she still needs to make, $\maroonD m$, we can use the equation $\maroonD m=\blueD{68} - \goldD c$.

To find the number of blocks Tegan still needs to make if she completes $\goldD{33}$ blocks, we can substitute $\goldD{33}$ into the equation for $\goldD c$.

$\begin{align} \maroonD m &=\blueD{68} - \goldD c\\
\maroonD m&=  \blueD{68} - \goldD {33}\\
\maroonD m &\maroonD{= 35}\end{align}$

The equation is $m = 68-c$

Tegan still needs to make $35$ blocks to finish the igloo.

question.content:
Tegan needs to make $68$ more snow blocks to finish building an igloo. 

**Write an equation for the number of  blocks Tegan still needs to make, $m$, when  she has completed $c$ blocks.**

[[☃ expression 1]]

Tegan completes $33$ blocks.

**How many blocks does Tegan still need to make to finish the igloo?**

[[☃ input-number 1]]  blocks

hints.content:
You pay $\blueD{\$80}$ for each month of karate lessons, and the number of dollars you spend depends on $\goldD m$, the number of months you take lessons.

To find the number of dollars you pay for karate lessons, $\maroonD d$, we can use the equation $\maroonD d=\blueD{80}\goldD m$. 

For example, when $\goldD {m = 4}$ we can multiply
$\blueD{ 80}\goldD{\times4} = \maroonD{320}$.

So, when $\goldD{m=4}$, then $\maroonD{d=320}$.

Let's complete the rest of the table:

$m$ | $d$
:-:|:-:
$1$ | $1\blueD{\times80} =80$
$2$ | $2\blueD{\times80} = 160$
$3$ |  $3\blueD{\times80} = 240$
$4$ |  $4\blueD{\times80} = 320$

The equation is $d=80m$.

The completed table is 

$m$ | $d$
:-:|:-:
$1$ | $80$
$2$ | $160$
$3$ |  $240$
$4$ |  $320$

question.content:
You sign up for karate classes. The classes cost $\$80$ per month.

**Write an equation for the number of dollars, $d$, that you pay for your karate classes if you take classes for $m$ months.** 

 [[☃ expression 1]]

**Complete the table for the missing values of $d$.**

$m$ | $d$
:-:|:-:
$1$ | $80$
$2$ | [[☃ input-number 1]]
$3$ | [[☃ input-number 2]]
$4$ | $320$

hints.content:
Duarte plays chess with his dad for  $\blueD{30}$ minutes. The number of minutes he has spent playing chess with his dad depends on $\goldD e$, the number of evenings they have played.

To find the number of minutes Duarte has played chess with his dad,  $\maroonD m$, we can use the equation $\maroonD m=\blueD{30}\goldD e$. 

For example, when $\goldD {e = 2}$ we can multiply
$\blueD{ 30}\goldD{\times2} = \maroonD{60}$.

So, when $\goldD{e=2}$, then $\maroonD{m=60}$.

Let's complete the rest of the table:

$e$ | $m$
:-:|:-:
$2$ | $2\blueD{\times30} =60$
$4$ | $4\blueD{\times30} = 120$
$6$ |  $6\blueD{\times30} = 180$
$8$ |  $8\blueD{\times30} = 240$

The equation is $m=30e$.

The completed table is 

$e$ | $m$
:-:|:-:
$2$ | $60$
$4$ | $ 120$
$6$ |  $180$
$8$ |  $240$

question.content:
Most evenings after dinner Duarte spends $30$ minutes playing chess with his dad. 

**Write an equation for the number of minutes, $m$, that Duarte spent playing chess with his dad if they played chess together $e$ evenings.** 

 [[☃ expression 1]]

$e$ | $m$
:-:|:-:
$2$ | $60$
$4$ | [[☃ input-number 1]]
$6$ | [[☃ input-number 2]]
$8$ | $240$

hints.content:
Tinley sets a pace so that each mile takes  $\blueD{7}$ minutes. The amount of time she spends on a run depends on $\goldD m$, the number of miles she runs.

To find the amount of time Tinley spends on a run,  $\maroonD t$, we can use the equation $\maroonD t=\blueD{7}\goldD m$. 

For example, when $\goldD {m=4}$ we can multiply
$\blueD{ 7}\goldD{\times4} = \maroonD{28}$.

So, when $\goldD{m=4}$, then $\maroonD{t=28}$.

Let's complete the rest of the table:

$m$ | $t$
:-:|:-:
$4$ | $4\blueD{\times7} =28$
$6$ | $6\blueD{\times7} = 42$
$8$ |  $8\blueD{\times7} = 56$
$10$ |  $10\blueD{\times7} = 70$

The equation is $t=7m$.

The completed table is

$m$ | $t$
:-:|:-:
$4$ | $28$
$6$ | $42$
$8$ |  $56$
$10$ |  $70$

question.content:
Tinley is training to run a half-marathon. She sets a pace so that every mile takes $7$ minutes. 

**Write an equation for the amount of time, $t$, it takes Tinley to run $m$ miles.**

:-:|:-:

$6$ | [[☃ numeric-input 1]]

$10$ | $70$

hints.content:
Sean needs to read for $\blueD{25}$ minutes. The total number of minutes he spends doing homework depends on the number of minutes he spends on his math problems, $\goldD m$.

To find out how many minutes Sean will spend on homework, $\maroonD h$, we can use the equation $\maroonD h=\goldD m \blueD{+ 25}$. 

For example, when $\goldD {m=15}$ we can add
$\maroonD h=\goldD {15} + \blueD{25}$. 

So, when $\goldD{m=15}$, then $\maroonD{h=40}$.

question.content:
Sean's mom asks him how long his homework will take. He tells her that he needs to read for  $25$ minutes and also do some math problems that will take $m$ minutes. All together, his homework will take $h$ minutes. 

**Write an equation for the number of minutes Sean's homework will take $h$, if his math problems take $m$ minutes.**

$30$ | $55$

hints.content:
To find out how many more points Sidney needs to score to tie her record, $\maroonD r$, we can use the equation $\maroonD r=\blueD{28}\goldD{- p}$. 

For example, when $\goldD {p = 10}$ we can subtract 
$\maroonD r=\blueD {28} \goldD{-10}  $. 

So, when $\goldD{p=10}$, then $\maroonD{r=18}$.

question.content:
The most points Sidney has scored in a basketball game is $28$. She is trying to tie  that record in her current game.

 [[☃ expression 1]]

$p$ | $r$
:-:|:-:
$10$ | $18$
$12$ | $16$
$14$ | [[☃ input-number 2]]
$16$ |[[☃ numeric-input 1]]

hints.content:
There are $\blueD{72}$ people planning to attend the beach clean-up. The number of people for whom supplies will be provided depends on the number of people who bring their own supplies, $\goldD b$.

To find out how many people supplies will need to be provided for, $\maroonD p$, we can use the equation $\maroonD p=\blueD{72} - \goldD b$. 

For example, when $\goldD {b = 30}$ we can subtract
$\maroonD p=\blueD{72} - \goldD {30}$. 

So, when $\goldD{b=30}$, then $\maroonD{p=42}$.

The equation is $p=72-b$

The completed table is

$b$ | $p$
:-:|:-:
$30$ | $42$
$40$ | $32$
$50$ |  $22$
$60$ |  $12$

question.content:
A group of $72$ people travel to the beach for a clean-up day. Some of the people bring their own supplies (such as gloves, water, and garbage bags).  Supplies are provided for the rest of the people.

**Write an equation for the number of people for whom supplies will be provided, $p$, if $b$ people bring their own supplies.** 

 [[☃ expression 1]]

**Complete the table for the missing values of $p$.**

$b$ | $p$
:-:|:-:
$30$ | $42$
$40$ | $32$
$50$ | [[☃ input-number 2]]
$60$ | [[☃ input-number 3]]

hints.content:
You pay $\blueD{\$6}$ for each box of strawberries. The number of dollars you spend depends on $\goldD b$, the number of boxes of strawberries you buy. 

To find the number of dollars you spend on strawberrries, we can use the equation $\maroonD d=\blueD6\goldD b$.

Remember, you want  to find the number of dollars you will spend if you buy  $\goldD2$ boxes  and $\goldD5$ boxes.

$\maroonD {12}=\blueD6\times\goldD 2$  
$\maroonD {30}=\blueD6\times\goldD 5$

Now we can turn the values for $b$ and $d$ from the equation into ordered pairs in the form $(\goldD x, \maroonD y)$. 

The ordered pairs are: $(\goldD2, \maroonD{12})$ and $(\goldD5, \maroonD{30})$.



Each $\goldD x$ value represents a number on the horizontal axis.

Each $\maroonD y$ value represents a number on the vertical axis.

The equation is $d=6b$.

The graph is

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e41d4038f3dd4550819545c7a4ab907112a4d080)

hints.content:
Enrique earns $\blueD{10}$ points for each question he answers correctly. The number of points he scores on the test depends on $\goldD x$, the number of questions he answers correctly.

To find the number of points Enrique scores on the test, $\maroonD y$, we can use the equation $\maroonD y=\blueD{10}\goldD x$.

Remember, you want to find the number of points Enrique scores on the test if he answers $\goldD{3}$ questions and $\goldD{7}$ questions correctly.

$\maroonD {30}=\blueD{10}\times\goldD{3}$  
$\maroonD {70}=\blueD{10}\times\goldD{7}$

Now we can turn the values from the equation into ordered pairs in the form $(\goldD x, \maroonD y)$. 

The ordered pairs are: $(\goldD{3}, \maroonD{30})$ and $(\goldD{7}, \maroonD{70})$.



Each $\goldD x$ value represents a number on the horizontal axis.

Each $\maroonD y$ value represents a number on the vertical axis.

The equation is $y = 10x$.

The graph is

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/26695ae495e1245560c4458234892507e0529144)

question.content:
Enrique earns $10$ points for each question that he answers correctly on a geography test.

**Write an equation for the number of points, $y$, Enrique scores on the test when he answers $x$ questions correctly.**

On his first geography test, Enrique answered $3$ questions correctly. On his second test, Enrique answered $7$ questions correctly.

hints.content:
You will spend $\blueD{2}$ times as many hours outdoors as you spend watching TV. The number of hours you spend outdoors depends on $\goldD t$, the number of hours you spend watching TV.

To find the number of hours you will spend outdoors, $\maroonD o$, you can use the equation $\maroonD o=\blueD{2}\goldD t$.

Remember, you want to find the number of hours you will spend outdoors if you spend $\goldD{4}$ hours watching TV and $\goldD{8}$ hours watching TV.

$\maroonD {8}=\blueD{2}\times\goldD{4}$  
$\maroonD {16}=\blueD{2}\times\goldD{8}$

Now we can turn the values from the equation into ordered pairs in the form $(\goldD x, \maroonD y)$. 

The ordered pairs are: $(\goldD{4}, \maroonD{8})$ and $(\goldD{8}, \maroonD{16})$.



Each $\goldD x$ value represents a number on the horizontal axis.

Each $\maroonD y$ value represents a number on the vertical axis.

The equation is $o=2t$.

The graph is

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2ec8b34e88b73215875a8f638d2a06d23acd5c6c)

question.content:
Although you love to watch TV, you have made a goal to spend more time outdoors. You decide that you will spend $2$ times as many hours outdoors as you spend watching TV. 

**Write an equation for the number of hours you will spend outdoors, $o$, when you spend $t$ hours watching TV.** 

 [[☃ expression 1]]


Last week, you watched $4$ hours of TV. This week, you watched $8$ hours of TV.

**Place points on the graph to show your activity for last week and this week.**


[[☃ interactive-graph 2]]

hints.content:
Mr. Ledger bought a total of  $\blueD{24}$ donuts. The number of donuts that are left at the end of the day depends on the number of donuts that are used during the lesson, $\goldD x$.

To find out how many donuts are left at the end of the day, $\maroonD y$, we can use the equation $\maroonD y=\blueD{24} - \goldD x$.

Remember, you want to find the number of donuts that are left at the end of the day if $\goldD{18}$ donuts and $\goldD{22}$ donuts are used during the lesson.

$\maroonD {6}=\blueD{24}-\goldD{18}$  
$\maroonD {2}=\blueD{24}-\goldD{22}$

Now we can turn the values from the equation into ordered pairs in the form $(\goldD x, \maroonD y)$. 

The ordered pairs are: $(\goldD{18}, \maroonD{6})$ and $(\goldD{22}, \maroonD{2})$.



Each $\goldD x$ value represents a number on the horizontal axis.

Each $\maroonD y$ value represents a number on the vertical axis.

The equation is $y = 24-x$.

The graph is 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9cc8991340031a8a331eab8ac636d890526520c8)

question.content:

hints.content:
Gian gets a total of  $\blueD{45}$ minutes to spend on the computer. The number of minutes he spends playing games depends on the number of minutes he spends watching videos, $\goldD x$.

To find out how many minutes Gian spends playing games, $\maroonD y$, we can use the equation $\maroonD y=\blueD{45} - \goldD x$.

Remember, you want to find the number of minutes Gian spends playing games if he spends $\goldD{5}$ minutes and $\goldD{25}$ minutes watching videos.

$\maroonD {40}=\blueD{45}-\goldD{5}$  
$\maroonD {20}=\blueD{45}-\goldD{25}$

Now we can turn the values from the equation into ordered pairs in the form $(\goldD x, \maroonD y)$. 

The ordered pairs are: $(\goldD{5}, \maroonD{40})$ and $(\goldD{25}, \maroonD{20})$.



Each $\goldD x$ value represents a number on the horizontal axis.

Each $\maroonD y$ value represents a number on the vertical axis.

The equation is $y = 45-x$.

The graph is 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d575d6d275720045ef6144bb6e3d4556ab572f17)

question.content:
Gian is allowed to spend $45$ minutes on the computer after dinner. He spends his entire $45$ minutes either watching videos or playing games.

**Write an equation for the number of minutes Gian spends playing games, $y$, if he spends $x$ minutes watching videos.**
